video_title: Worth it? How the xTool P2 CO2 Laser Stacks Up Against the Competition
comment_text: Xtool advertising is misleading. They say the P2 works with Lightburn (with exception of auto focus, cameras and curve feature). Given i already have a D1 and Lightburn works perfectly with it, I had no reason to assume Lightburn wouldn't work with the P2 with the exception of the explicitly stated limitations above.  I can understand not having the curve support, but all other functions should be available. Also, the XCS software is horrible. I would not expect it to be on par with LIghtburn, but there are a multitude of little things like being able to easily define layers or remove the close up view when not needed. All in all, unless you are happy to only work in XCS (assuming full support for Lightburn never comes), save your money and buy another brand CO2 (Monoport, Omtech) and get a fiber laser to go with it for what you pay for the P2. I am posting this comment not as a criticism of the this video, but in the hopes that someone watching this video in trying to decide whether to buy the P2 or not, are more fully informed. I did a fair amount of research before buying the P2 and everyone either intentionally or unknowingly failed to mention just how limited LIghtburn for P2 is nor just how bad the XCS software is.

video_title: You Could Lose Your Job To This.
comment_text:
I think you are spot on in your analysis. You went back to 1928, but let’s go further back: We saw the same trends with new technologies like electricity, the steam engine (revolutionised the weaving industry), the wheel…. Each time, we have seen new jobs emerge as a result.

For woodworkers, we can be divided into two categories: Some are production focussed, churning out the same chairs, tables, coasters every day in as high a volume as possible. For them, automation will be a God-send as they will be able to produce more a day. The other category are the more “creative” (no offence, producers) that hardly ever make two identical products. Here, machines may replace certain steps, but not the entire creative and assembly process. It’s especially the creative work that AI cannot replace - at least for many years to come.

video_title: You Could Lose Your Job To This.
comment_text:
You asked for feedback, so here goes with the caveat that not every channel should be for everyone and every creator should have the space to evolve.
I'm just here for information about tools and process, not the larger context. For the current machine learning wave as a topic, I'd be interested in seeing what you can *do* with it but if I want a historical or economic perspective (both topics notoriously filled with misinformation) then  I'll go read or watch a historian or an economist.
But, like I said, just because it's not for me doesn't mean it's not for others and it definitely doesn't mean that you shouldn't head in new directions with the channel.

people like to make the argument that because the industrial revolution didn't decimate jobs the ai revolution won't either. these aren't even close to the same. industrial revolution was the creation of machinery that did specific tasks. ai revolution is the replication of fluid human intelligence and senses while also leveraging unimaginable quantities of data. 80 percent or more jobs will be gone at a minimum. white collar will start to go first. universal basic income will be rolled out at some point. the majority of those who work in the future will be either enhanced or fully dedicated to climbing dominant hierarchies - top 5 percent achievers. mega corporations and government will fully merge. globalism fully implemented - elimination of national sovereignty. i estimate around 50-100 years for the ruling class of world to get this done.    

there's no direction away from the current trajectory because public awareness is shifted into left / right tribalism and whatever the news cycle dictates.

comment_text: Great video. It helped me a lot. A general tip that is valid for most instruction videos. At least use a yellow halo around your cursor (can be created within Windows). Since it is so small and the screen is packed with functions it is often hard to see  where the cursor is on the screen. I have worked with Camtasia in the past that would automatically zoom in at your cursor position which is even better. Camtasia is pretty expensive but I bet the cheaper options like OCB (free) will have similar functionality.

video_title: Do Lasers Ruin 3D Printer’s? Bambu Lab H2D Laser Review
comment_text:
I'm so glad i found your video! You are getting a sub from me!
I have been looking at getting a 3D printer, but had to put the purchase on pause due to another big purchase (an affordable house!) and then this bad boy dropped! My partner got excited and asked me if i would rather save up a little more money and then get this 2 in one, because i would like to try laser cutting but its not my main focus and the machines are rather expensive. 
So here i am trying to research if the printer is worth it or not and from your review, which was sooo much more helpful since you know the details about laser cutting and most other reviewers are 3D printers, and i think i feel like this is a 100% the route i should go, i get to have the 3D printer i wanted but as an added bonus i can play around with the laser cutter function and it sounds like the quality and what you get is quite good even though the size is a trade off.
But i am also a hobbyist, i love trying my hand at many hobbies and i don't think i need a bigger surface to cut on to begin with, so honestly it really sounds like a great fit for someone like me, who needs the 3D printer but would love to try a laser cutter too :)

comment_text: So because Bambu doesn't have an official honeycomb bed, they do however mention on the wiki and documentation that there are optional 'laser grid panels' which sit on top of the slats (which you can buy more of btw on the store right now) the grid panels are a very nice addition but according to support are not available yet, they cover the bed with up to 3 of them, see the wiki for photos (I can't post a url in YouTube comments it just deletes the comment) you can also 3D print the grid panels, search MakerWorld for 'Printable Grid Plate for H2D' its by 'CutMaster', it's almost identical to the Bambu ones but they are available now of course for printing.

video_title: The Fiber Laser to Get in 2025? xTool F2 Ultra Review
comment_text: Great video! I already own a very nice gantry CO2 laser and an open-frame (split fiber) 60W MOPA, but I've been looking for a (relatively) portable machine for doing on-site engraving. I pulled the trigger on an F2 Ultra ultimately because not only does it hit all the requirements for what I need in a machine for on-site work at shows (both in versatility *and* safety), it's work area is large enough that when needed, I can supplement the workload handling of the split fiber MOPA I have. So for me and my use cases, the extra expense of the F2 Ultra made sense.

video_title: $300 Ink?! The REAL Cost of the EufyMake UV Printer

video_title: Do Lasers Ruin 3D Printer’s? Bambu Lab H2D Laser Review
comment_text:
I believe that opening the vent enables air INTO the machine which can then go to the exhaust. Without the vent opening, this sealed machine will have no way for fresh air to get into the machine at a high enough volume to not starve the filter. It’s clever, as the vent is in the front top, while the exhaust is in the middle height at the rear. So this gives you an air flow that goes right through the shortest distance, which happens to be the area where the laser is working.

If the size of the bed is ok for people and you just don’t have the room, then this is fine. The quality seems to be pretty good. As far as the different time scales for the laser or the printer, well, you just have to manage your time. If you know what you’re going to be doing, then do the short job first. These things are a compromise. If you’re willing to accept that, then it’s great. If you can’t, then this isn’t the machine for you. But don’t forget this also cuts and draws. This might be useful and it may not.
